company.name: RockYou, Inc.
company.business_description: RockYou, Inc. operated a website and online service accessible worldwide on the Internet through RockYou.com where users could develop content, create and share widgets (including slideshows), and register to save content for later retrieval and editing.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

complaint.factual_background: RockYou, Inc. operated a website that collected personal information from consumers but failed to implement basic data security measures, resulting in unauthorized access to approximately 32 million email addresses and passwords. Additionally, from December 2008 through January 2010, RockYou knowingly collected personal information from approximately 179,000 children under age 13 without obtaining parental consent or providing proper notice, in violation of COPPA requirements.

representations_made.description: Claimed to use commercially reasonable physical, managerial, and technical safeguards to preserve the integrity and security of personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: 1 RockYou! uses commercially reasonable physical, managerial, and technical safeguards to preserve the integrity and security of your personal information. We cannot, however, 2 ensure or warrant the security of any information you transmit to RockYou! and you do so at your own risk. Once we receive your transmission of information, RockY ou! 3 makes commercially reasonable efforts to ensure the security of our systems. However, please note that this is not a guarantee that such information may not be accessed, 4 disclosed, altered, or destroyed by breach of any of our physical, technical, or managerial 5 safeguards. (Exhibit A, www.rockyou.com Privacy Policy, February 13,2006)

representations_made.description: Claimed not to knowingly collect or maintain personally identifiable information from persons under 13 years of age
representations_made.quoted_text: Protecting the privacy of young children is especially important. For that reason, RockYo u! does not knowingly collect or maintain personally identifiable information or 26 non-personally-identifiable information on the RockYou! Sites from persons under 13 27 years of age, and no part of our website is directed to persons under 13. If you are under 13 years of age then please do not use or access the RockYo u! Sites at any time or in any 28 manner. If RockY ou! learns that personally identifiable information of persons under 13 omplaint for Permanent Injunction, Civil Penalties, and Other Relief Page 7 of12

representations_made.description: Stated that if RockYou learns that personally identifiable information of persons under 13 has been collected, it will take appropriate steps to delete this information
representations_made.quoted_text: 28 manner. If RockY ou! learns that personally identifiable information of persons under 13 omplaint for Permanent Injunction, Civil Penalties, and Other Relief Page 7 of12 1 years of age has been collected on the RockY ou! Sites without verified parental consent, then RockYou! will take appropriate steps to delete this information. Exhibit A (Privacy

counts.title: Data Security Misrepresentation
counts.representation: Defendant represented that it implemented reasonable and appropriate measures to protect against unauthorized access to the personal information it obtained from customers
counts.fact: Defendant did not implement reasonable and appropriate measures to protect against unauthorized access, including: unnecessarily collecting email passwords, storing passwords in clear text, failing to segment servers, and not protecting against SQL injection and XSS attacks
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 15 was false or misleading and constituted a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: COPPA Rule Violations
counts.representation: Defendant collected, used, and/or disclosed personal information from children
counts.fact: Defendant failed to: provide sufficient notice on its website of information practices; provide direct notice to parents; obtain verifiable parental consent; and establish reasonable procedures to protect confidentiality, security, and integrity of children's personal information
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant has violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.

counts.title: Misrepresentation About Children's Information Collection
counts.representation: Defendant represented that it: (a) did not knowingly collect or maintain personal information from children under 13; and (b) would delete any personal information that it learns it has collected from children
counts.fact: Defendant knowingly collected, and did not delete, personal information from children under 13
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representations set forth in Paragraph 35 above were false and misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.
definitions.child: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.collects: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.collection: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Commission: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.delete: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.disclosure: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Internet: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.online contact information: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.operator: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.parent: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.person: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.personal information: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.third party: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.verifiable consent: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.website or online service directed to ch: defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Consumer personal information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) a driver's license or other state-issued identification number; (g) a financial institution account number; (h) credit or debit card information; (i) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie," a static Internet Protocol ("IP") address, or processor serial number; (j) nonpublic communications and content posted on Defendant's web site or within Defendant's applications provided on any other web site; or (k) any information that is combined with any of (a) through (j) above.
definitions.Defendant: RockYou, Inc., a corporation, its successors and assigns and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule in connection with any website or online service directed to children.

requirements.description: Must not fail to provide sufficient notice of information collected from children as required by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Children's Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from making any misrepresentation concerning the collection, use, disclosure, or deletion of children's personal information.

requirements.description: Must not make any misrepresentation concerning the collection, use, disclosure, or deletion of children's personal information in connection with operation of any website or online service

provisions.title: Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish and implement a comprehensive information security program to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of consumer personal information.

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial assessments from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional for 20 years.

requirements.description: Obtain initial and biennial assessments from qualified, objective, independent third-party professional using procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor compliance with this Order through various means including requests for reports, depositions, document production, interviews, and other lawful discovery methods.

requirements.description: Within 14 days of receipt of written request from Commission representative, Defendant must submit additional compliance reports or other requested information sworn under penalty of perjury, appear for depositions, and produce documents for inspection and copying
requirements.quoted_text: AA.. requirements.description: Commission may use all other lawful means, including posing as consumers, suppliers, or other individuals or entities to Defendant or any affiliated individual or entity, without the necessity of identification or prior notice

duration.termination_text: For 20 years following entry of this Order, Defendant must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within 14 days of any change... Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order... each 2 year period thereafter for 20 years after service of the Order for the biennial Assessments.
